item.title: Syrian Family in Sweden Feels Tug of Ailing Sibling Left Behind
item.media:description: Widad Majid, 10, center, held a cousin, also named Widad, at the Syrian family’s new home in Backhammar, Sweden.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Majids made it through Europe to safety in a tiny settlement, with thoughts of family members who stayed behind and the mother country they left.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: PEN America Enlists Writers to Urge Egypt’s Leader to Free Author
item.media:description: Ahmed Naji, 30, an imprisoned Egyptian author, in an undated photo in Cairo.
item.media:credit: Yasmin Hosam El Din, via Associated Press
item.description: More than 120 prominent figures signed a letter calling on President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi to release Ahmed Naji, imprisoned for a novel the government said was immoral.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Ambush Kills 8 Police Officers in Egypt
item.media:description: Eight officers were killed after an unmarked police minibus was attacked in Cairo on Sunday.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility after four assailants opened fire on a minibus carrying plainclothes officers in a district of Cairo.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.S. Role in Afghanistan Turns to Combat Again, With Tragic Result
item.media:description: Patients were treated after an American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in October. The accidental bombing killed 42 people.
item.media:credit: Doctors Without Borders/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Green Berets’ descriptions of a battle with the Taliban in Kunduz, where an airstrike killed 42 people at a hospital, reflected the blurry parameters of the American mission.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: White House Letter: Obama Weighs Visiting Hiroshima or Nagasaki
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan in Washington last year. Mr. Obama, who will attend a summit meeting in Japan this month, once said he would be “honored” to visit Hiroshima and Nagasaki during his presidency.
item.description: On the president’s trip to Japan this month, a visit to the cities where America dropped atomic bombs could highlight the horrors of nuclear weapons, but could also risk being seen as an apology.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Fort McMurray, a Canadian Boom Town, Is Left Smoldering in Ashes
item.media:description: Evacuees from the wildfire taking refuge at the Bold Center in Lac La Biche, Alberta, 137 miles south of Fort McMurray, on Saturday.
item.description: Fast-moving wildfires have consumed entire swaths of a town that had drawn residents with fat paychecks and second chances, though some residents vow to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Fort McMurray Fire Begins to Ease as Weather Cools
item.media:description: Smoked drifted over trees south of Fort McMurray, Alberta, on Sunday. The path of a fire that began a week ago shifted away from the city and toward a heavily forested and unpopulated area.
item.description: Firefighters prepared to contain the Alberta blaze as officials started planning for residents’ return, but disruptions continued for companies involved in oil sands operations.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Seeing President Mugabe’s Frailty, Zimbabwe Braces for Turmoil
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. At 92, he is the world’s oldest head of state.
item.description: Anxiety and cutthroat politics grip a nation that has known no other leader as Robert Mugabe, 92, shows increasing signs of aging, even talking about his own mortality.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO

item.title: Close Encounters With Jets Show Russia’s Anger at NATO Buildup, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Russian soldiers marched in Red Square on Sunday during a rehearsal for the Victory Day military parade.
item.description: Obama administration officials interpreted three incidents involving fighter jets in the last month as a warning to stay out of the Baltics, but said that would not happen.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: In Sichuan Province, an Artisan Retreats to China’s Past
item.media:description: Han Shan, an artisan textile dyer from the mountains of Guizhou Province, says that China’s modernization has come at a price: Society has lost its connection with nature.
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times
item.description: Disillusioned with China’s urban dream, a young man set off on a 15-year walk and rediscovered his family’s ethnic Miao traditions.
item.dc:creator: JONAH M. KESSEL

item.title: Santa Bárbara D’Oeste Journal: A Slice of the Confederacy in the Interior of Brazil
item.media:description: A woman in a traditional hoop skirt walked past graves adorned with Confederate battle flags in Santa Bárbara d’Oeste, Brazil. An annual celebration of the area’s Confederate many settlers was held in the cemetery last month.
item.description: A city in São Paulo State that Americans fled to after the Civil War still celebrates Dixie culture, without dwelling on slavery or the battle flag.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Collision of Buses and Fuel Truck in Afghanistan Kills More Than 50
item.media:description: An Afghan man who was injured in a crash involving two buses and a fuel truck was brought to a hospital in Ghazni Province on Sunday.
item.description: The crash, in Ghazni Province in the southeastern part of the country, injured scores of other people, many of them critically.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sufi Muslim Leader Killed in Latest Hacking Attack in Bangladesh
item.description: The police said it was too early to say whether the attack was done by Islamist militants, who have claimed responsibility for several such killings recently.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Pakistani Rights Activist Is Shot and Killed in Karachi
item.media:description: The coffin of Khurram Zaki, who was killed in a drive-by shooting on Saturday, was carried during his funeral in Karachi, Pakistan, on Sunday.
item.description: Khurram Zaki, a blogger, campaigned against both religious extremism and the head cleric of a radical mosque.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Australian Leader Calls for National Elections in July
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia announcing on Sunday that national elections will be held July 2.
item.description: The election will be the first time Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and the opposition leader Bill Shorten have faced each other on the ballot.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: North Korea Claims Its Nuclear Arsenal Is Just a ‘Deterrent’
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, speaking before an assembly of the nation’s ruling Workers’ Party.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: Kim Jong-un says Pyongyang would only resort to using its cache of atomic weapons if its national sovereignty were breached or threatened.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: After Tragedies, Nepal Hopes for an Uneventful Year for Everest Climbers
item.description: After two years of tragedy, a drop in climbing numbers this year and a confluence of safety concerns, much is at stake.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: 3 Journalists Missing in Syria Have Been Freed, Spain Says
item.description: The Spanish journalists, who disappeared last July, were freed from captivity with the help of Turkey, Qatar and other allies, Spain said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Conservative’s Star Rises in Brazil as Polarizing Views Tap Into Discontent
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, a Brazilian congressman, center, in Brasilia in March at a protest calling for President Dilma Rousseff’s removal.
item.description: The national prominence of Jair Bolsonaro, a member of Congress, reflects a veering to the right and a growing dissatisfaction with the political establishment.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Refugees From Syria Among the Thousands Who Fled Canadian Fire
item.media:description: The Beacon Hill neighborhood of Fort McMurray on Saturday, days after a wildfire destroyed hundreds of homes and vehicles.
item.description: “Our bad luck followed,” said one woman, who lost her eyeglasses in the rush to evacuate a fire that has no obvious end.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and DAN LEVIN

item.title: Mexico Moves Drug Lord Known as El Chapo to Prison Near Texas
item.description: The convicted drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera, who twice escaped from jail, was transferred to a prison in northern Mexico near the border with Texas.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thai Activist’s Mother Faces Prison Term for One-Word Facebook Reply
item.description: The woman had sent the reply “Ja,” similar to saying “Yeah,” in response to a private message that the police say insulted the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Philippine Presidential Race Devolves Into Sideshows Amid Serious Issues
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte
item.description: Rodrigo Duterte, the front-runner heading into Monday’s elections, has made several outlandish statements.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: What in the World: 25 Seconds That Could Save a Firefighter’s Life (or Not)
item.media:description: Government-issue fire shelters.
item.description: A fire shelter is mandatory equipment when fighting a wildfire in the United States, but in Canada, firefighters stopped carrying them in 2005.
item.dc:creator: FERNANDA SANTOS

item.title: What in the World: Rents in London? If You Have to Ask ...
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin, Photo by nok nok/shutterstock.com
item.description: An average apartment in London now costs nine-tenths of an average worker’s pay.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: What in the World: A Nickname for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi? There’s No Short Answer
item.media:credit: Cari Vander Yacht and Erik Blad
item.description: Western notions of first and last names don’t really apply in Myanmar, presenting a quandary for people who speak or write about its leading political figure.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: What’s That You’re Wearing? A Guide to Muslim Veils
item.description: Veils for Muslim women come in all sizes, shapes and colors — and with terminology that can mean different things in different places.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Haqqanis Steering Deadlier Taliban in Afghanistan, Officials Say
item.description: A militant network the United States considers a terrorist group is playing a greater role in the insurgency, raising fears of worsening fighting ahead.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Taliban Publicly Execute Two Women in Northern Afghanistan
item.description: One victim was killed in her yard in what was apparently an honor killing; the other execution was captured on a video.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Saudi King Shakes Up Government as Economic Plan Moves Forward
item.media:description: Among the changes announced Saturday was the replacement of the country’s long-serving oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, who is in his 80s.
item.description: King Salman issued a new wave of royal decrees, replacing a number of top ministers and restructuring government bodies.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Sex Talk for Muslim Women
item.description: I realized I had to speak frankly about my own sexual experience to free others to do so, too.
item.dc:creator: MONA ELTAHAWY

item.title: Opinion: Spring on the Afghan Front Lines
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: He pointed to houses on the horizon: “Taliban. Taliban. Maybe Taliban.”
item.dc:creator: DANIELLE MOYLAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: U.S. Policy Puts Iran Deal at Risk
item.description: A shoot-yourself-in-the-foot approach undermines Obama’s major diplomatic achievement.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
